arm_group.description: During treatment, the AMES device rotates the hand and then the wrist, into flexion and extension, while the patient assists with this motion.  At the same time, the AMES device provides sensory stimulation by vibrating the tendons of muscles stretched by the movement.  The vibratory stimulus switches from one side of the limb to the other when the rotation reverses direction so that the sensory stimulation remains functionally related to the movement. This study provides for 25 AMES treatments over 8-13 weeks, at a rate of 2-3 sessions per week.

brief_summary.textblock:
In this study, an FDA-approved device and type of treatment called "AMES," which stands for
      Assisted Movement with Enhanced Sensation, will be used to determine whether sensation in
      the upper limb of individuals with incomplete spinal cord injuries improves along with
      movement through treatment. We hypothesize that measureable improvement in the sensation of
      upper limb will precede improvement in functional movement.

clinical_study.brief_title: Proprioception Testing in Persons With Sensorimotor Impairment

detailed_description.textblock:
The AMES device performs tests of sensorimotor impairment as well as deliver therapy.  In
      this study, we are testing 2 additional diagnostic tests (i.e., Joint Position Test and
      "Frisbee" Test), both of proprioception, in order to determine which of the two is the best
      test of proprioception.  Our hypotheses are: (1) both sensation and movement recover with
      AMES treatment, (2) sensory recovery precedes that of movement, (3) robotic delivery of the
      Joint Position Test produces more reliable test results than does manual delivery of this
      test, and (4) the Frisbee Test results will parallel those of the Joint Position Test.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Traumatic incomplete SCI subjects with tetraplegia.

          -  At least 1 year post spinal cord injury.

          -  Able to tolerate sitting upright at for at least 1 hour.

          -  On the ASIA sensory function (skin touch) component, a score of at least 1 for the C6
             and T1 levels, and a minimum combined score of 3 for levels C5-T2.

          -  On the ASIA motor function component, a total score of 3-9 for finger flexors, wrist
             extensors, and finger abductor/adductors and a minimum score of 1 for the finger
             flexors and for the finger abductor/adductors.

          -  Cognitively and behaviorally capable of complying with the regimen.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Fracture of the treated limb resulting in loss of range of motion.

          -  Progressive neurodegenerative disorder.

          -  DVT of the treated extremity.

          -  Uncontrolled seizure disorder.

          -  Uncontrolled high blood pressure/angina.

          -  Combined score on ASIA motor function for finger flexors, wrist extensors, and finger
             abductor/adductors outside the range of 3-9.

          -  Contractures equal to or greater than 50% of the normal ROM.

          -  Concomitant TBI or stroke (Patients who sustained mild head injury during the trauma
             with no evidence of structural abnormalities on brain images will qualify for the
             study).

          -  Botox treatment of the treated extremity in the prior 5 month.

          -  Chronic ITB therapy.

          -  Peripheral nerve injury of the treated extremity.

          -  Osteo- or rheumatoid-arthritis limiting range of motion.

          -  Pain in affected limb or exercise intolerance.

          -  Participation in another therapy or activity-based program.

          -  Skin condition not tolerant of device.

intervention.description: During the therapy session, the AMES device rotates the hand and wrist into flexion and extension, while the patient assists with this motion, as possible.  At the same time, the AMES device provides sensory stimulation by vibrating the tendons of muscles stretched by the movement.  The vibratory stimulus switches from one side of the limb to the other when the rotation reverses direction so that the sensory stimulation remains functionally related to the movement. The subject will receive visual bio-feedback of their contribution to the motor movement.

contact.last_name: Linda D Cordo, RN, BSN, MSN

clinical_study.official_title: Proprioception Testing in Persons With Sensorimotor Impairment

other_outcome.description: Sensory test using the Biothesiometer to measure perception of vibration
Testing proprioceptive sensation, the subject attempts to identify the direction of wrist movement as the Evaluator randomly moves the subject's wrist in flexion and extension.
other_outcome.time_frame: After each treatment on the AMES device.

other_outcome.description: The AMES device measures the torque generated by the subject when he/she attempts to make a maximum flexion and maximum extension.
other_outcome.time_frame: After each treatment on the AMES device.

other_outcome.description: The subject, using the AMES device, generates a numerical score by moving the wrist joint through a range of movement following a moving target with times breaks.
other_outcome.time_frame: After each treatment on the AMES device.

overall_contact.last_name: Linda D Cordo, RN, BSN, MSN

oversight_info.authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

primary_outcome.description: Testing proprioceptive sensation, the subject attempts to identify the direction of wrist movement as the AMES device randomly moves the subject's wrist in flexion and extension.
primary_outcome.time_frame: After each treatment on the AMES Device

reference.citation: Cordo P, Lutsep H, Cordo L, Wright WG, Cacciatore T, Skoss R. Assisted Movement With Enhanced Sensation (AMES): Coupling Motor and Sensory to Remediate Motor Deficits in Chronic Stroke Patients. Neurorehabil Neural Repair. 2009 Jan-Feb;23(1):67-77. Epub 2008 Jul 21.

secondary_outcome.description: Testing proprioceptive sensation, the AMES device moves the subject's wrist through a 30 degree range, at variable speeds, as the subject attempts to identify when their wrist reaches a particular target.  The subject receives feedback about the accuracy of the testing.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: After each treatment on the AMES device.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
